How do you get 1024? Please avoid magic mumbers.
It is from buffer size and it is changed to recvBufSize for better meaning in new patch set.

As section "26.1 GetPDRRepositoryInfo command", the `repositorySize` field 
```
Size of the PDR Repository in bytes. This value provides information that can be used for
helping estimate buffer size requirements when accessing PDRs.
This size covers only the cumulative sizes of the PDR record fields. This size does not
include the size for any internal header structures that are used for maintaining the PDRs.
This number does not report and may not directly correlate to the amount of internal storage
used for PDRs because, for example, an implementation may elect to internally compress or
use other encodings of the PDR data.
An implementation is allowed to round this number up to the nearest kilobyte (1024 bytes).
```
Use requestCnt = 1024 is reasonable.

How are we planning to handle when we support multiple MCTP networks? Duplicate EIDs are possible in that case. It will be better if we can have some directions to avoid future redesigns.

As per specification TIDs should be unique but not EID. So we can have a map with terminus as key 
```
std::map<std::shared_ptr<Terminus>, 
     mctp_eid_t /* or MctpInfo or TransportIdentifier */> termini{};
```

OR
we can have something like
```
std::map <MctpInfo, std::shared_ptr<Terminus>> termini{}
```
Where MctpInfo can have EID, UUID/NetworkID

For supporting other transport layer, the map key is changed to use tid.
The NetworkID is included in MctpInfo.
The toMctpInfo() can lookup terminus's MctpInfo by tid.

its a good coding practice to `include what you use`. This is what google's c++ style guide says :

`
If a source or header file refers to a symbol defined elsewhere, the file should directly include a header file which properly intends to provide a declaration or definition of that symbol. It should not include header files for any other reason.

Do not rely on transitive inclusions. This allows people to remove no-longer-needed #include statements from their headers without breaking clients. This also applies to related headers - foo.cc should include bar.h if it uses a symbol from it even if foo.h includes bar.h.
`

https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html#Include_What_You_Use
